doc.title: Chemical Metal Watch
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/Cu foiloptical connectorscables exports firm fewer refined petrochem imports Japan trade statistics for July Thai trade _2025-08-29

passages.text: Exports of Mitsui Mining & Smelting's copper foil (likely MicroThin foil) stood out for their strength. Exports of Fujikura's optical connectors and cables, Nitto Boseki's glass cloth, and SUMCO's silicon wafers also remained strong. On the other hand, exports of Shin-Etsu Chemical's silicon wafers lacked strength. This was likely a pullback from the exports of high- end products in the previous term. JSR's photoresist exports remained strong, providing a positive datapoint for photoresist makers.

In July, export prices were weak for Tosoh's petrochemical products, such as MDI, VCM, caustic soda and ethylene amine. Denka had healthy export volumes for spherical alumina, spherical silica and acetylene black. Mitsubishi Gas Chemical saw a large increase in exports of polyacetal from Thailand. Export prices for Daicel's acetate tow remained firm. Exports of Mitsui Chemicals' lens monomers declined \(8.3\%\) YoY. Japan's agrochemical exports fell sharply, down \(42.7\%\) YoY. Exports of carbon fiber textile rose significantly. This is a positive datapoint for Toray Industries. Imports of PE and PP rose significantly. Exports of refined petroleum products were weak for ENEOS but increased at Idemitsu Kosan. Imports of four light distillates (white fuels) fell \(33.1\%\) YoY in July, easing supply- side pressure. This is a positive datapoint for oil refiners.
Imports of three types of thin steel products into Japan fell \(3.9\%\) YoY in July but rose sharply MoM. Export prices for steel products fell sharply at both Nippon Steel and JFE.

Toyota Motor's July production volume rose \(5.2\%\) YoY. Sales data for Toyota Motor improved in regions related to Toyota Tsusho and Mitsui & Co. In contrast, Toyota Motor's sales data related to Sumitomo Corporation was weak.

BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH

We derive our 7,650 price objective based on a P/E of 18x our FY3/27 forecasts, using a multiple lower than the average of the 13.5- 31.5x P/E range since April 2023, when growth for Al servers accelerated.

Downside risks to the share price are (1) a decline in sales of Nittobo's glass fiber products due to slowdowns in the electronics industry, such as for smartphones, base stations, or servers, (2) sharp yen appreciation (each 1 appreciation against the dollar erodes annual OP by an estimated 150mn), and (3) sharp rises in crude oil prices (each \$1/bbl increase in the crude price erodes annual OP by an estimated 80mn). Upside risks are (1) stronger- than- expected momentum in the electronics industry, (2) sharp yen depreciation, and (3) sharp declines in crude oil prices.

Our price objective (PO) of 1,300 is based on a P/E of 12.5x on our FY12/27 EPS estimate. The multiple is the upper limit of its range of 8- 12.5x during 2022- 23. We factor in the degree of earnings recovery going into FY12/27. Downside risks to our PO are (1) sharp yen appreciation (1/5 appreciation reduces annual OP by 1.1bn, (2) an abrupt slowdown in the semiconductor market, and (3) major inventory valuation loss of polysilicon due to loss making in gross income.

Our PO for Tosoh is 2,050, based on a P/E of 10.0x and our FY3/27 estimate. This multiple is higher than the median of the historical 10- year range of 4- 13x, a reflection of the major improvement in shareholder returns compared with the past, and the higher profit contribution from consolidated subsidiary Organo, which is seeing strong growth. Upside risks are (1) yen depreciation, (2) lower raw material and fuel prices, (3) stronger demand for building construction around the world and (4) structural reforms and environmental regulations in China's vinyl chloride sector. Downside risks are (1) rapid yen appreciation, (2) a sharp increase in raw material and fuel prices, (3) a drop in global demand for building construction, and (4) regulatory changes creating a need to
investment heavily in coal-fired power plants stemming from the loss of cheap electricity from coal-fired power plants.

We base our price objective of \(1,650 on a P/E of 13.5x our FY3/27 EPS estimate. We apply a 15% discount to the 16x median of Denka's historical P/E range of 7.5- 24.5x to reflect slower OP growth through FY3/28.

Downside risks to our PO are (1) a sharp slowdown in the market for LiBs, (2) a sudden fall in the price and resulting margin deterioration on chloroprene rubber, (3) a sharp slowdown in demand for COVID- 19 test kits and influenza vaccines. Upside risks are (1) sharp expansion in the market for LiBs, (2) a sudden increase in the price of chloroprene rubber, and (3) sharp expansion in demand for COVID- 19 test kits and influenza vaccines. We estimate that depreciation of \(1\) against the US dollar boosts Denka's annual OP by \(\) 50\mathrm{mn}\$ .

Our price objective is \(\) 5,300\(. This is derived by multiplying our FY3/27 EPS estimate by a P/E of 18x, above the median of last 10 years range, 8 - 28x. We think this level is appropriate in light of stronger growth potential in earnings. Downside risks are a sudden decline in demand for semiconductors, a sudden decline in global demand for PVC resin, and a rapid appreciation of the yen (each\) 1/ USD stronger JPY depresses annual RP by \(4.0bn\) . Upside risks are a sharp rise in semiconductor demand, sharp increase in global PVC resin demand and weaker JPY.

Our PO for Mitsubishi Gas Chemical is \(\) 3,200\(, based on a P/E of 15.0x on our FY3/27 EPS estimate. This multiple is near the high end of the P/E range of 6.5 - 16.5x since 2020, a level we view as appropriate in light of expansion in the Al server market and the company's strong growth potential in electronic materials.

Downside risks to our PO are: (1) sharp declines in demand for electronic materials, (2) sharp yen appreciation (we estimate each \(1\) appreciation against the dollar erodes annual RP by \(0.5bn\) ) and (3) significant impairment losses. Upside risks are: (1) sharp expansion in adoption of its electronic materials in Al servers, such as BT materials, and (2) sharp yen depreciation.

Our PO for Mitsui Chemicals of \(\) 3,000\(is based on P/E of 10.5x using our FY3/27 estimates, which is the average of Japanese diversified chemical companies. Upside risks to our PO are (1) sharp decline in raw material prices, and (2) brisker petrochemical demand in Japan and elsewhere in Asia. Downside risks are (1) a sharp rise in raw material prices, and (2) major impairment loss of domestic petrochemical facilities. \(\) 1/ USD\(depreciation may push up its annual OP by\) \ \(1bn\) .
Our PO of \(\) 1,170\(is based on a P/E of 7x our FY3/27 EPS estimate. This multiple is broadly on par with Daicel's average P/E of 6.5x over the past two years when acetate tow margins were strong.

Downside risks to our PO are 1) yen appreciation ( \(1\) rise vs. US\$ depresses annual OP by \(0.8bn\) ), 2) a sharp rise in methanol prices (we estimate Daicel uses 500,000 tons of methanol a year, a US\$10/ton rise in methanol prices raises costs by \(750mn\) ), 3) a sharp decline in thermal coal prices (we estimate Daicel uses 600,000 tons of thermal coal a year, a 10\$/ton rise in thermal coal prices raises cost by \(800mn\) ), 4) a weak auto market, and 5) competitors adding acetate tow capacity. Upside risks are 1) yen depreciation, 2) a sharp decline in methanol prices, 3) a sharp decline in thermal coal prices, 4) a boom in automobile demand, and 5) unanticipated growth in cigarette demand.

We derive our 12- month PO of \(\yen 1,140\) by applying a P/E of 7.5x to our FY3/27 EPS estimate (ex- inventory impact). Idemitsu's total shareholder payout ratio target is \(50\%\) (based on net profit ex- inventory impact) and a stable DPS of \(\yen 36\) . We expect high shareholder returns to support share price.

Upside risks: (1) the normalization of Nghi Son Refinery's operations, contributing to earnings and significantly reducing the risk of losses, (2) a steep increase in thermal coal prices, and (3) a steep increase in petrochemical and oil prices.

Downside risks: (1) a deterioration in Nghi Son Refinery's operations due to a funding shortfall, leading to large losses (a construction completion guarantee of \(\yen 110.3bn\) at end- FY3/25), (2) a steep decline in thermal coal prices, and (3) a steep decline in petrochemical and oil prices.

Our price objective (PO) of \(\yen 860\) is derived from our FY3/27 EPS estimate of \(\yen 101.8\) (adjusted to exclude inventory valuation effects) and a P/E of 8.5x. Our PO basis multiple of 10x is higher than the 9x average P/E since April 2020 based on EPS excluding inventory valuation effects, from a range of 6- 18x. We have added a premium of around \(10\%\) to the average to reflect the improvement in shareholder returns. We think ENEOS's earnings foundation is stronger than it was in the past, as there already has been considerable consolidation among domestic oil refiners, paving the way for stable margins. And we expect a high dividend yield and generous shareholder returns backed by this stability to support the share price. Upside risks are (1) sharp increase in the price of crude oil, copper, and other commodities, (2) a substantial improvement in refining margins, and (3) a rapid improvement in margins for paraxylene, propylene, and other petrochemicals margins. Downside risks are (1) sharp decrease in the price of crude oil, copper, and other commodities, (2) a substantial deterioration in refining margins, and (3) a rapid deterioration in margins for paraxylene, propylene, and other petrochemicals margins.

Our \(\yen 3,050\) PO is based on a P/E of 9.0x our FY3/27 EPS estimate. This P/E is higher than the middle of historical range (4- 11x) due to future growth potential. Downside risks are deterioration in steel margins from lower volumes, steep increases in raw material costs and dividend cut. Upside risks are improvement in steel margins from higher volumes, lower raw material costs and rising steel prices.

We derive our \(\yen 1,750\) price objective from a FY3/27 P/E of 9.5x. We use a premium to the average 6.5x P/E in FY3/19, a period of improving earnings. Downside risks to our investment rating are (1) dramatic deterioration in overseas steel markets, (2) falling domestic steel market volumes and prices owing to a major influx of steel imports, (3) a higher interest burden resulting mainly from increased interest rates, and (4) an unexpectedly sharp rise in decarbonization costs. Upside risks are (1) dramatically improved overseas steel market prices, (2) sharply higher domestic steel market demand, and (3) reduced decarbonization costs and the creation of technology to help decarbonize steelmaking.

Our price objective for Mitsui Mining & Smelting is JPY7,400, based on a FY3/27 P/E of 13x. We use the top of the 5- 13x range during past growth periods (2016- 18). Considering the high- growth phase of the artificial intelligence market, we believe it is appropriate to use the high- end valuation.

Downside risks to our PO are (1) sharp yen appreciation (every \(\yen 1/5\) in yen strength adversely impacts annual RP by \(\yen 500\) mn), (2) a steep decline in zinc market prices, (3) fiercer competition for MicroThin foil and VSP foil, and (4) rapidly falling copper foil

volumes owing to factors such as technological change. Upside risks are (1) rapid yen depreciation, (2) sharply higher zinc market prices, and (3) substantial copper foil demand growth alongside developments such as technological change and AI server advances.
Our PO of ¥3,600 is based on our FY3/27 estimate and a P/E of 9.0x, which represents the median value of 9x for the 5- 13x P/E range since 2020.

Downside risks to our PO are (1) a sharp slowdown in Toyota Motor's auto production volume, (2) an economic downturn in emerging markets (Africa, Eastern Europe/Russia, Oceania, etc.), (3) a significant slowdown in the outlook for the renewable energy market, and (4) the sale of shares by major shareholders Toyota Motor or Toyota Industries. Upside risks are (1) increased auto production at Toyota Motor, (2) sharp improvement in emerging market economies and a sudden rise in renewable energy prices, and (3) major shareholders boosting their stake in the company.

Our price objective is JPY3,400 (ADR \(468.97\)). This is derived from a P/E of 12.0x our FY3/27 EPS estimate. We apply a premium to the roughly 11x midpoint of the 6.5- 15x range in 2006- 08. We apply this premium because we forecast a total return ratio of around 50% on core operating cash flow from FY3/26.

Upside risks are (1) sharp increases in iron ore and crude oil prices, (2) rapid recovery in automobile sales, and (3) a dividend hike or share buybacks against a backdrop of strong commodity prices. Downside risks are (1) sharp declines in iron ore and crude oil prices and (2) a steep decline in automobile sales.

Our ¥4,750 PO (ADR \(32.76\)) is based on a P/E of 10.0x our FY3/27 EPS estimate. We use the roughly midpoint of the 6.5- 14x range in 2006- 08. We forecast a total return ratio of around 40% from FY3/25, while ROE should also remain high owing to persistently strong profit. We estimate that the stock will return to previous high valuations.

Upside risks are (1) a sharp increase in US shale gas and oil drilling activities owing to a recovery in energy prices, (2) a thriving real estate market with improvement in Tokyo metropolitan area office market conditions, and (3) substantial improvement in Ambatovy project earnings on things like better operating rates and sharp growth in nickel prices.

Downside risks are (1) a sharp decline in commodity prices (iron ore, zinc, nickel, thermal coal, etc.), (2) rapid worsening of leasing business, (3) a sharp decline in infrastructure segment profit because of stricter regulations regarding coal- fired power generation, (4) unexpectedly poor production at nickel mine and smelter Ambatovy, and (5) unexpectedly large impairment charges.

FUNDAMENTAL EQUITY OPINION KEY: Opinions include a Volatility Risk Rating, an Investment Rating and an Income Rating. VOLATILITY RISK RATINGS, indicators of potential price fluctuation, are: A - Low, B - Medium and C - High. INVESTMENT RATINGS reflect the analyst's assessment of both a stock's absolute total return potential as well as its attractiveness for investment relative to other stocks within its Coverage Cluster (defined below). Our investment ratings are: 1 - Buy stocks are expected to have a total return of at least \(10\%\) and are the most attractive stocks in the coverage cluster; 2 - Neutral stocks are expected to remain flat or increase in value and are less attractive than Buy rated stocks and 3 - Underperform stocks are the least attractive stocks in a coverage cluster. An investment rating of 6 (No Rating) indicates that a stock is no longer trading on the basis of fundamentals. Analysts assign investment ratings considering, among other things, the 0- 12 month total return expectation for a stock and the firm's guidelines for ratings dispersions (shown in the table below). The current price objective for a stock should be referenced to better understand the total return expectation at any given time. The price objective reflects the analyst's view of the potential price appreciation (depreciation).
Investment ratingTotal return expectation (within 12-month period of date of initial rating)Ratings dispersion guidelines for coverage clusterR2Buy≥ 10%≤ 70%Neutral≥ 0%≤ 30%UnderperformN/A≥ 20%
R2Ratings dispersions may vary from time to time where BofA Global Research believes it better reflects the investment prospects of stocks in a Coverage Cluster.

INCOME RATINGS, indicators of potential cash dividends, are: 7 - same/higher (dividend considered to be secure), 8 - same/lower (dividend not considered to be secure) and 9 - pays no cash dividend. Coverage Cluster is comprised of stocks covered by a single analyst or two or more analysts sharing a common industry, sector, region or other classification(s). A stock's coverage cluster is included in the most recent BofA Global Research report referencing the stock.
